message: Awesome post!! I am new to TPL and was having an issue grasping how to update the progress using a task from anther class. This helped out immensely! Thanks!
Excellent post. Can you throw up a VB version? I've tried running the code through the online converters and the functions with generics won't convert/compile. Thanks.

Hello Peter -  

I haven't written in VB since... '96. :) I'm sure that there are converters available that can understand generics.  

I tried this one, and the results look OK to me:  
 [http://www.developerfusion.com/tools/convert/csharp-to-vb/](http://www.developerfusion.com/tools/convert/csharp-to-vb/)

Stephen,  

Thanks for a really great article. I am struggling with one of the concepts and while I am likely to use your ProgressReporter class, I want to grok it.  
Feel free to respond to my question on StackOverflow if you are inclined and have the time.  

Thanks again for the article. Very well written.

Hey Stephen,  
Just wanted to say really awesome article, was struggling with using tasks with the progress bar all day yesterday and your article really helped  

just wanted to say thanks :-D

Hi,  
Thanks for great post. But there is one not good feature. For example, I use four cascades of four tasks. There are not flags for correct parallel work from second cascade of tasks. Calculations are in continue mode but not in parallel kind. It seems that system is busy after first four tasks.  
ContinueWith gives only flag from main task. But ContinueWith and ReportProgress is separate tasks (internally). There is not way to dispose it...

Nice post.  
But I find it a bit odd that the ProgressReporter handles what a task should continue with after it's done (RegisterContinuation). This is a mix of responsibilies and does not fit the class name.

This is significantly more work and more complex than just using the BackgroundWorker class. The nice thing about the backgroundWorker class is it encapsulated all of the heavy lifting underneath the hood. This technique really forces you to know the mechanics of how each class functions and the proper way to wire them up together.

Will,  

I'm working on an update to this post that shows off the way async Tasks report progress. It uses a similar technique to ProgressReporter, but is built-in to the Async CTP (and Visual Studio vNext), so it will end up being even easier to use than BackgroundWorker.  

Also, it will nest naturally, which is BGW's biggest weakness.
The update message at the top of this post just points back to the same post.
Thanks! I recently refreshed the site design, and a few things broke. This is now fixed. :)

Hi Stephen,

I am wondering if you can describe the benefits of last approach. I appreciate it. Thank you

The code in this post is very old, and uses several techniques that I do not recommend. See here for a more updated approach: [http://blog.stephencleary.com/2012/02/reporting-progress-from-async-tasks.html](http://blog.stephencleary.com/2012/02/reporting-progress-from-async-tasks.html)
Duly noted

You should use IProgress<t>/Progress<t>, as noted in the updated article.

For an example, see here: [http://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/09/taskrun-vs-backgroundworker-round-5.html](http://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/09/taskrun-vs-backgroundworker-round-5.html)
ProgressReporter is recommended ? Now, in 2017, which the good patterns and practices about it ? Any full sample (WinForms) using good patterns and practices now? Thx.

You'd need to pass it in somehow. For simple code, you can use lambda variable capture:  
 [https://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/09/taskrun-vs-backgroundworker-round-5.html](https://blog.stephencleary.com/2013/09/taskrun-vs-backgroundworker-round-5.html)

Or you could use a member variable, as is done in this post.

Otherwise, yes, you'd need to pass it in manually.
